prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will conduct the observations of the redshifted 12CO (J=2-1) emission line from the sample of 8 Luminous Infra-Red Disk Galaxies at z=1.03-1.22. The CO (2-1) line of the rest-frame frequency of 230.538 GHz is redshifted to 103.61GHz ? 115.15GHz and can be observed in Band 3. The targets are selected as they show Spitzer MIPS 24μm flux larger than 130μJy. The rest-frame 12 μm luminosity, ν12 L12 (L?), is converted to the total Infrared luminosity, L(IR) (L?), following the empirical relation discussed in Chary and Elbaz (2001). The expected total line flux, L’CO (Kkm/s pc2) was then estimated by using the L(IR)/L’CO luminosity ratio for star-forming galaxies, ~27 L?/(K km/s pc2), as well as the CO(1-0)/CO(2-1) ratio, ~1.2, studied in Genzel et al. (2010), which are listed in Table1. The total flux is then calculated by using the formula in Solomon et al. (1997). SCO(2-1) ΔV ~ 750-1500 mJy km/s will be observed. Since these galaxies are extended to ~3 arcsec (see Fig. 6 in Scientific Justification), the CO lines may be spatially resolved if we use the extended array configuration. We prefer the beam size of 1.0”. While the average flux per beam shall be ~100 mJy km/s, we also expect the cases that the observed flux is dominated by some large clumps in the disk. Assuming the observed velocity width of ~200km/s (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010), the expected average flux, S(CO), will range ~0.5-5mJy. So we need the sensitivity (1σ/ beam) of ~0.1mJy, which can be achieved ~1hour integration at 110 GHz with the spectral resolution of ~50km/s, which is useful to investigate the internal kinematics of the galaxies. If the line is strong and significantly detected, we may investigate the velocity profile with typically ~20 -30km/s resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We here propose ALMA CO (2-1) line observations of the Disk Galaxies at z~1 which have large infrared luminosity, L(IR) > 10^11L⦿ (LIRG). The LIRG population at z~1 is likely to be dominated (90%) by the evolving disk galaxies which frequently show the features of clumpy starburst in their disks. These “LIRG-Disk” galaxies also occupy more than half (60%) of the massive disk galaxies at z~1. With the ALMA cycle2 capability, we conduct CO(2-1) observations in Band-3 for the sample of 8 representative LIRG-Disk galaxies in GOODS-South field to (i) detect CO lines from the resolved starburst clumps, to evaluate the molecular gas mass fraction in the clumps to constrain how much , and (ii) study the kinematic structure of the entire disk and clumps. The uniqueness of the proposal is to observe the sample well defined in morphology (disk) and high star-formation rate (LIRG), yet at the luminous end of the star-formation main sequence at the redshift. By observing the object bridging the local massive spiral galaxies and further disturbed galaxies at higher redshift (z>2), we obtain important clues in understanding the formation histories of the disk galaxies.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Research Center for Space and Cosmic Evolution, National University Corporation Ehime University
School of Science, The University of Tokyo
